Hmm, didn\'t thought I will post it but there is just no free time to get my little station ready. So here is a shot of the first version:
Looks awesome! What\'s on the bottom-most node, facing us. The goldish dome-top tank?

Looks awesome! What\'s on the bottom-most node, facing us. The goldish dome-top tank?

Thanks ;D It\'s a core module (made it a strut) from Probodobodyne with one little tank and the space probe engine. Kind of a little escape craft for the station.

Sweet Mother of Kesus, Shedao! The sun called, he wants all his power back.

The farside mission had lowball station, a small (munar-orbiting) space station, but it\'s really only big enough for a few kerbins. It looks bigger because it still has the last-stage fuel tank attached. I think all the stations posted here so far have (a lot) more Kerbin-habitable elbow room.
Yes, it orbits!

The issue with those is that they only connect to one of the three stacks. The other two are disconnected.

I remember that, yeah. But with struts you can make it work semi-correctly.

They still look good though.

It occurred to me recently: What the heck does the ISS do with all that heat? Every watt of energy you get from the sun, you have to then turn around and get rid of once you\'ve turned it into waste heat.

Google: what did we do without you?

http://www.lockheedmartin.com/products/HeatRejectionRadiators/index.html

So fun fact: Some of those things sticking out of the ISS that I always assumed were solar panels, are actually quite the opposite: photo voltaic radiators, designed to get rid of all the heat absorbed from the sun and produced by the ship.

Learn new things every day.
Can you tell us what parts packs you used and give me a link to download the .craft file?
